Question: Can coronavirus travel by wind
Answer: Coronavirus cannot travel very far in the air, the World Health Organization says.

Question: Should I stop wearing contacts and switch to glasses
Answer: There is no evidence to suggest contact lens wearers are more at risk for acquiring COVID-19 than eyeglass wearers.

Question: Can you safely reuse a non-cloth mask that you can’t wash, like a disposable mask
Answer: Yes you can, said Dr. Joseph Vinetz, an infectious diseases professor at Yale School of Medicine.

Question: What’s so different about coronavirus that we have to shut down businesses
Answer: Unlike SARS and swine flu, the novel coronavirus is both highly contagious and especially deadly, CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said.

Question: Will ingesting or injecting disinfectants, like the ones that kill viruses on surfaces, protect me against coronavirus or kill coronavirus if I already have it
Answer: “That’s a bad idea,” said Dr. Colleen Kraft, an infectious diseases professor at Emory University School of Medicine. “It could definitely kill you.”

Question: Can mosquitoes transmit coronavirus
Answer: No.

Question: Is it true young people with coronavirus are also having blood clots and strokes
Answer: Yes, some young adults have subered strokes after getting coronavirus.

Question: Why worry about coronavirus when the flu kills so many people
Answer: The number of Americans killed from Covid-19 and those who have died from the flu this season are now comparable. But deaths from Covid-19 are happening at a much faster rate.

Question: Why can’t we just test everyone in the US
Answer: Doctors say it’s not realistic to test all 328 million people in the US, especially since many states are still struggling to get enough tests or testing supplies.

Question: Do I need to wash my clothes right after encountering other people, like at the grocery store or while jogging
Answer: Coronavirus can stay alive for up to three days on stainless steel and plastic. But clothing is probably more like cardboard — it’s more absorbent, so the virus is unlikely to stay and last that long.

Question: Can coronavirus spread through water
Answer: There is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs.

Question: How can someone spread coronavirus when asymptomatic
Answer: When you speak, sometimes you’ll spit a little bit. You’ll rub your nose. You’ll touch your mouth. You’ll rub your eyes. And then you’ll touch other surfaces, and then you will be spreading virus if you are infected and shedding asymptomatically.

Question: Can you get coronavirus from touching money — either cash or coins
Answer: Viruses can live on surfaces and objects — including on money — although your chance of actually getting COVID-19 from cash is probably very low.

Question: Will an antibody test show whether I’m immune and can go back to work
Answer: Not necessarily. Antibodies are a body’s response to bacteria or viruses. But this novel coronavirus is so new, it’s still not clear whether having antibodies to it means you have long-term protection from getting reinfected.

Question: If novel coronavirus antibodies may or may not offer long-term immunity, how would a vaccine help
Answer: In some cases, a vaccine might give stronger protection than antibodies produced after being infected, epidemiologist.

Question: What are the odds that the US can reopen by May 1
Answer: “May 1st, I think, is completely unrealistic,” said Dr. Ashish Jha, director of the Harvard Global Health Institute.

Question: Are some blood types able to fight this coronavirus better than other blood types
Answer: “With this respiratory virus, (as) with other coronaviruses, no,” said Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove, technical lead for the World Health Organization’s Covid-19 response.

Question: Can I use vodka as hand sanitizer
Answer: The CDC advises using hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.

Question: Are smokers or vapers at higher risk
Answer: This is not a good time to be vaping or smoking anything.

Question: Can I get coronavirus through food
Answer: There’s no evidence that coronavirus can be transmitted through food.

Question: Does this pandemic have anything to do with the 5G network
Answer: No. That’s just a hoax going around the internet.

Question: How long does coronavirus stay “alive” on surfaces
Answer: Up to three days, depending on the surface.

Question: After recovering from coronavirus, does a person have long-term immunity to the virus
Answer: It’s too early to know for sure.

Question: Will a pneumonia or flu vaccine help protect against coronavirus
Answer: Some cases of coronavirus do lead to pneumonia. But the pneumonia vaccine won’t help

Question: Should I wear a face mask in public
Answer: The CDC “recommends wearing cloth face coverings in public settings where other social distancing measures are diffcult to maintain.

Question: How long will we have to keep social distancing
Answer: Probably for several months. But you might have to do it over and over again, since the outbreak could come in waves.

Question: Why is a cure taking so long
Answer: An antiviral drug must be able to target the specific part of a virus’s life cycle that is necessary for it to reproduce, according to Harvard Medical School.

Question: Why are medical workers getting sick with or dying from coronavirus if they’re wearing protective gear
Answer: Many health care workers don’t actually have enough protective gear to handle the growing influx of coronavirus patients.

Question: Can I have the flu and coronavirus at the same time
Answer: Yes. Testing positive for either the flu or coronavirus doesn’t exempt you from having the other at the same time.

Question: Should all Americans be under stay-at-home orders
Answer: “We really should be,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, a member of the White House Coronavirus Task Force.

Question: How many people with coronavirus don't have symptoms
Answer: Recent studies suggest 25% to 50% of coronavirus carriers don’t have symptoms.

Question: If there’s no cure, why go to the hospital unless you have a breathing problem
Answer: Most coronavirus patients don’t need to be hospitalized. “The vast majority of people – about 80% – will do well without any specific intervention,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.

Question: Can high or low temperatures kill coronavirus
Answer: Generally coronaviruses survive for shorter periods of time at higher temperatures and higher humidity than in cooler or dryer environments. However, we don’t have direct data for this virus, nor do we have direct data for a temperature-based cutob for inactivation at this point,

Question: Is the water supply at risk
Answer: No, the water supply is not at risk.

Question: Is coronavirus more contagious than the flu
Answer: Yes. Research indicates a person with the flu infects about 1.28 other people, on average. But with the novel coronavirus, it’s likely between 2 and 3 other people.

Question: If people can spread the virus without showing any symptoms, how can I tell who’s infected and who’s not
Answer: You can’t, said Dr. James Phillips, chief of disaster and operational medicine at George Washington University Hospital.

Question: How does this coronavirus spread
Answer: It primarily spreads between people through respiratory droplets, like through coughs, sneezes, spittle.

Question: How long is someone contagious after getting coronavirus
Answer: It varies. Decisions about when a person can be released from isolation are made on a case-by-case basis.

Question: What exactly does 'older' adults mean
Answer: The average age of death for people from coronavirus is 80. Average age of people who need medical attention is age 60.

Question: Are kids more at risk
Answer: Younger people seem to be insulated to some extent to protect them from getting particularly sick.

Question: Is coronavirus especially harmful for pregnant women
Answer: Researchers do not have information from published scientific reports about susceptibility of pregnant women to this coronavirus.

Question: What can I do if my loved one suspects they have coronavirus
Answer: Don’t visit family members with suspected illness – keep up with them virtually.

Question: Should I disinfect my groceries
Answer: “I would suggest wiping down external surfaces of canned or wrapped foods,” said Dr. Celine Gounder, an infectious disease specialist at Bellevue Hospital Center.

Question: Should I stock up on extra food and supplies
Answer: Yes, because a family member may suddenly have to quarantine.

Question: Should I avoid public transportation
Answer: If you rely on public transportation, use caution. If you’re sick or live in an area where an outbreak has been reported, avoid it.

Question: How do I stay healthy while using Uber or Lyft
Answer: Both rideshare companies said they’re actively trying to protect customers and drivers from coronavirus.

Question: Is it safe for me to vote at a polling location
Answer: States have received guidance from the CDC on how to keep voting locations clean. It’s up to you whether you feel comfortable going.

Question: Should I go to work
Answer: If you can, you should stay home from work when you’re sick, whether or not you have coronavirus.

Question: Can I be fired if I stay home sick
Answer: An employee can be fired if they don’t show up to work and they don’t have sick leave that would cover the absence.

Question: What happens when workers don't get paid sick leave
Answer: The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) can sometimes protect a worker’s job in the event they get sick, but it won’t guarantee they get paid while they’re out.

Question: Can managers send a sick worker home
Answer: Yes, managers can.

Question: If traveling on a plane, how do I stay safe
Answer: It’s not the cabin air you need to worry about. It’s keeping your hands clean.

Question: Since a plane's cabin keeps circulating air, will I get sick if another passenger is sick
Answer: Most viruses don’t spread easily on airplanes because of how the air circulates and is filtered.

Question: If I have a weakened immune system, should I cancel my travel plans
Answer: People who are immunocompromised are at higher risk from this illness, as well as other illnesses like the flu. Avoiding contact with ill people is crucial.

Question: What do I do if I think I’m sick
Answer: Stay home. Call your doctor to talk about your symptoms and let them know you’re coming for an appointment so they can prepare for your visit.

Question: What’s the best way to prevent coronavirus
Answer: Stay at least 6 feet away from others, and wash your hands often.

Question: Should I spray myself or my kids with disinfectant
Answer: No. Those products work on surfaces but can be dangerous to your body.

Question: I’ve heard that home remedies can cure or prevent the virus. Is that true
Answer: There’s no evidence from the outbreak that eating garlic, sipping water every 15 minutes or taking vitamin C will protect people from the new coronavirus.

Question: If infected with coronavirus, can you survive it and recover
Answer: Absolutely. The vast majority of people with coronavirus survive.

Question: How long does it take to recover
Answer: It takes anything up to six weeks to recover from this disease.

Question: Why waste a test kit on a person without symptoms
Answer: Some people with coronavirus have mild or no symptoms. And in some cases, symptoms don’t appear until up to 14 days after infection.

Question: Why is the US so far behind other countries with testing
Answer: Experts say it’s due to cuts in federal funding for public health and problems with early testing.

Question: If a coronavirus patient progresses to pneumonia, what antibiotics if any have proven to be effective
Answer: No, antibiotics are not effective against coronavirus because the disease is a viral infection, not a bacterial infection.

Question: Can the heat from a hand dryer kill coronavirus
Answer: Hand dryers can’t kill the virus.

Question: Can I get coronavirus from a package sent from China
Answer: No. The new coronavirus cannot be transmitted through goods manufactured in China or any country reporting Covid-19 cases
